Phosphorous-doped carbon coordinated iridium diphosphide bifunctional catalyst with ultralow iridium amount for efficient all-pH-value hydrogen evolution and oxygen reduction reactions Jiahuan Zhao Zonghua Pu Huihui Jin Zhiwei Zhang Jing Liu Shichun Mu ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Advanced Technology for Materials Synthesis and Processing, Wuhan University of Technology, Wuhan, Hubei 430056, PR China State Key Laboratory of Advanced Technology for Materials Synthesis and Processing Wuhan University of Technology Wuhan Hubei 430056 PR China State Key Laboratory of Advanced Technology for Materials Synthesis and Processing, Wuhan University of Technology, Wuhan, Hubei 430056, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Ultralow noble metal loading catalyst is one of the current main research trends for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). In this context, we synthesize the phosphorus-doped carbon covered IrP2 catalysts (IrP2@PC) with Ir amount merely about 1 wt% by an extremely simple way. It possesses remarkably high HER performance, exceeding commercial Pt/C and most reported transition metal catalysts in the whole pH range. In alkaline electrolytes, it shows an ultralow overpotential of 10 mV at a current density of 10 mA·cm−2, almost 100% Faradaic yield for hydrogen production, and continuous discharge stability for more than 10 h. At the same time, in acidic and neutral electrolytes, its overpotentials at the same current density are as low as 15 and 32 mV, respectively. Interestingly, linear Sweep Voltammetry (LSV) data present that, under alkaline conditions, IrP2@PC also possesses a half-wave potential of 0.81 V, extremely close to commercial Pt/C catalysts, indicating that the catalyst also possesses outstanding ORR performance. Keywords Bifunctional catalyst Iridium diphosphide Hydrogen evolution reaction Oxygen reduction reaction All-pH-value 1 Introduction The development and utilization of new energy sources is the main method to solve the issues of traditional energy consumption and environmental pollution [1]. As we know, hydrogen considered as a clean renewable energy source has the potential to replace fossil fuels [2–4]. The hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) plays a vital role on hydrogen generation. Similarly, efficient oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is important in the renewable energy platform particularly for fuel cells and metal-air (O2) batteries [5–8]. Up to now, Pt-based noble materials are still the best catalysts for both HER and ORR [9,10]. However, high-price and rare sources seriously limit their widespread applications [11,12]. In response to this problem, non-noble transition metal (Mo, Ni, W, Co, Fe) catalysts have been widely explored [13–25]. However, most of their catalytic efficiency is still much lower than Pt catalysts, and they generally own a single catalytic performance in very small pH ranges. Transition metal phosphides (TMPs) have been demonstrated new and promising HER catalysts due to their outstanding physicochemical properties. TMPs own more electronegative phosphorous (P) atoms that can induce the local charge density and adapt to surface charge states [26]. Thus, most of TMPs show better activity than the corresponding pure metals [27–29]. Our group reported that Rh2P-NC had higher HER catalytic activity and better stability than Pt/C over the whole pH range [30]. Qin et al. demonstrated that RuP and RhxP nanoparticles possessed good ORR and OER properties [31]. Zhang et al. prepared carbon nanotube supported MoP with excellent HER performance over the full pH range [3]. However, they usually used hypophosphite as the source of P with release of PH3, which is highly flammable, toxic, corrosive and harmful to the environment [32]. And they also used H2 as the reducing agent, which is prone to the danger of explosion. Note that both iridium (Ir) and platinum (Pt) elements belong to group VIII, and have similar physical and chemical properties. But Ir-based TMPs have rarely been studied as multifunctional catalysts for HER and ORR. It is well known that porous carbon materials have high surface area and excellent electron transfer capability. Wang et al. fabricated Metal @N-Doped Carbon Catalysts via a thermal method that prove the carbon layers can effectively prevent agglomeration of nanoparticles [33,34]. In addition, it is also possible to increase the stability of TMP during the catalysis process [35,36]. In particular, the uneven spin density and charge distribution that occur after introduction of heteroatoms further promote the electron transfer and catalytic reaction [11,37,38]. Herein, for the first time, we successfully obtain a P-doped carbon (PC) covered IrP2 nanocrystal core-shell skeleton (IrP2@PC) catalyst with ultralow Ir loading. It can be prepared by using environmentally friendly phytic acid (PA) as phosphorus source and a convenient reaction with IrCl4·xH2O (Fig. 1 ). The synergy between IrP2 and PC exhibits excellent HER catalytic performance and stability over the full pH range and high ORR performance in alkaline media. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthesis of IrP2@PC catalysts To synthesis IrP2@PC-0.63, IrP2@PC-0.96 and IrP2@PC-1.41, 6, 12 and 24 mg of IrCl4·xH2O were poured into 2 ml of phytic acid solution, respectively, with ultrasonic dispersion for half an hour. The mixture was poured into the porcelain boat, then place the porcelain boat in the middle of the quartz tube of the tube furnace. After purging with N2 gas for one hour, heat up the tube furnace from room temperature to 850 ℃ at 5 ℃/min. Keep the temperature for 2 h, then naturally cooled to room temperature. The collected product was dispersed in 20 ml of dilute hydrochloric acid, refluxed for 24 h, washed several times with deionized water, and the product was dried in a vacuum oven to obtain the product IrP2@PC. The step of synthesis for PC was identical to those described above except add IrCl4·xH2O. 2.2 HER measurements The HER performance was tested in electrolyte of 0.5 M H2SO4, 1 M KOH, and 1 M PBS solutions, respectively. 5 mg of the catalyst was dispersed in a dispersant composed of 10 μL 5 wt% Nafion solution and 1000 μL ethanol. The catalyst ink was prepared by sonication for about 0.5 h. 5 μL of the catalyst ink was dropped onto a smooth 3 mm glassy carbon electrode (loading amount: 0.35 mg/cm−2), and naturally dried at room temperature to prepare a catalyst electrode. All electrochemical tests were performed on CHI 750D electrochemical workstation. All electrochemical tests were performed in a conventional three-electrode system. A 3 mm glassy carbon electrode was used as the working electrode. Graphite rod was used as counter electrode, and a saturated calomel electrode (SCE) was used as reference electrode. All polarization curves are corrected by iR. The electrochemical impedance frequency spectrum (EIS) measures from 100 kHz to 0.1 Hz with an ac frequency of 10 mV. By using the midpoint specific capacitance of 40 μF cm−2, the ECSA is determined as: ECSA = Cdl/Cs. 2.3 ORR measurements The electrolyte was 0.1 M KOH. 5 mg of the catalyst was dispersed in a dispersant composed of 10 μL 5 wt% Nafion solution and 1000 μL ethanol. The catalyst ink was prepared by sonication for about 0.5 h. 10 μL of the catalyst ink was dropped onto a smooth 5 mm glassy carbon electrode (loading amount: 0.23 mg/cm−2), and naturally dried at room temperature to prepare a catalyst electrode. All electrochemical tests were performed on a CHI 750D electrochemical workstation. The operation was carried out in a three-electrode system with rotating disc. Ag/AgCl electrode is reference electrode and platinum wire is counter electrode. Before the test, we aerate oxygen for 0.5 h to make the solution saturated. The electron transfer number was calculated by Koutecky-Levich equation using RDE technique (see Supporting information). 2.4 Structural characterization XRD measurements were performed on a Bruker D8 advance XRD system using CuKa radiation. XPS testing was performed on an ESCALAB 250Xi/ESCALAB 250Xi X-ray photoelectron using a spectrometer Al Ka as the excitation source. SEM imaging was performed by using a ZEISS-Merlin field emission microscope to set an acceleration voltage of 5 kV. The HAADF-STEM imaging test was performed by using a JEM-2100F at an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. The ICP test was performed with Prodigy 7. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure of IrP2@PC catalysts IrP2@PC nanocatalysts were obtained by annealing the mixture of phytic acid and IrCl4·xH2O in an N2 environment. To compare the effect of different Ir loadings on the performance, three catalysts with extremely low amount of Ir contents of 0.63 wt%, 0.96 wt% and 1.41 wt% were prepared, respectively, and determined by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) analysis. As shown in Fig. S1 (ESI†), the main diffraction peaks in the powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern can be attributed to the monoclinic phase of IrP2 (JCPDS No. 13-0212). Fig. S2 (ESI†) shows SEM images of IrP2@PC-0.96. We can see that the carbon covered IrP2 nanoparticles are very small and evenly distributed. Furthermore, Fig. 2 shows the images of transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) of IrP2@PC-0.96. As exhibited in Fig. 2a, IrP2 nanoparticles are uniformly covered with the carbon layer. To further verify it, XPSwithArgon-ionetching processes was carried out to unveil the information of content distribution for Ir with depth. (Fig. S3) (ESI†) Through etching, the content of Ir is gradually increasing with depth (Table S1) (ESI†), evidencing that the IrP2 nanoparticles are covered with the carbon layer. The average size of IrP2 NPs in diameter (Fig. 2b) is about 2.0 nm. Fig. 2c shows a TEM image of nanocrystals for IrP2@PC-0.96 with a specific lattice spacing of 0.369 nm and 0.289 nm corresponding to the IrP2 (−1 1 1) and IrP2 (0 2 0) planes. From the HRTEM image (Fig. 2d), it reveals that the surface of IrP2 nanocrystals is indeed covered by a thinner porous carbon layer. High-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM), and EDX element mapping (Fig. 2e–i), further unveil that C, P, O and Ir elements are uniformly distributed in IrP2@PC-0.96, evidencing the presence of IrP2 and P-doped carbon layers. According to nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherm of IrP2@PC-0.96 (Fig. S4) (ESI†), the specific surface area based on the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) model is 1182.5 m2·g−1, and the pore size distribution (Fig. S4) (ESI†) shows the characteristic microporous and mesoporous structures [39]. From the full X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) spectra of IrP2@PC-0.96 (Fig. 3 ) and PC (Fig. S5) (ESI†), they also manifest the existence of Ir, C, P, O elements and unveils the surface electronic states of IrP2@PC-0.96. As shown in Fig. 3b, the subpeaks at 61.2 and 64.2 eV are consistent with the binding energy (BE) of Ir4+ 4f7/2 and Ir4+ 4f5/2 of IrP2 [40,41]. For the high-resolution C 1 s spectrum, the peaks appearing at 284.5 eV 285.3 eV and 288.9 eV are attributed to C=C, C-P, O-C=O, respectively [42,43]. In the high-resolution P 2p spectrum of IrP2@PC-0.96, the peaks at 134.8 eV and 132.5 eV are assigned to P-O and P-C, respectively. The peak at 129.8 eV presents a slightly negative shift of 0.3 eV relative to the peak of the standard P2p3 at 130.1 eV [28], indicating that it can be attributed to P-Ir [29,44]. In the high-resolution O 1 s spectrum of IrP2@PC-0.96, the peaks at 532.7 eV and 530.6 eV are ascribed to C-O and C=O, respectively [45]. In the Raman spectrum (Fig. 3f), the ratio of ID to IG is 1.08, indicating that the carbon matrix in IrP2@PC catalysts are quite disordered [46]. 3.2 HER performance of catalysts In electrochemical testing, a three-electrode system configuration was carried out where the 3 mm glassy carbon electrode, graphite rod and saturated calomel electrode (SCE) were used as the working electrode, counter electrode and reference electrode, respectively. The catalytic activity of IrP2@PC-0.63, IrP2@PC-0.96 and IrP2@PC-1.41 in different pH electrolytes was investigated at a scanning rate of 5 mV·s−1. For comparison, the catalytic performance of commercial Pt/C (20 wt%), Ir/C (10 wt%) and PC was also examined under the same test conditions. It is noted that almost rare HER catalysts have an excellent activity in both acidic, neutral and alkaline media, because for the conversion of H2O in a neutral or alkaline medium, it is typically about 2–3 orders of magnitude lower than that in an acidic medium [47]. As shown in Fig. 4 a and b, in the alkaline medium of pH = 14 (1 M KOH), both IrP2@PC-1.41 and IrP2@PC-0.96 exhibit ultralow overpotentials of 10 mV and 25 mV, respectively, at a current density of 10 mA·cm−2, much lower than that of Pt/C (38 mV). Their corresponding Tafel slopes are 49 mV·dec-1 and 58 mV·dec-1, respectively. By contrast, Ir/C and PC require larger overpotentials (290 mV, 403 mV) to achieve a current density of 10 mA·cm−2. Interestingly, as shown in Table S2 (ESI†), the HER activity of IrP2@PC-1.41 is higher than that of most recently reported catalysts for alkaline HER. As shown in Fig. 4c, Tafel slopes of IrP2@PC-1.41 and IrP2@PC-0.96 are 49 mV·dec-1 and 58 mV·dec-1, respectively. Such small Tafel slope values are close to Pt/C. Meanwhile, we also measured the cyclic stability under alkaline conditions. The continuous water electrolysis on the IrP2@PC-0.96 electrode for 10 h at a constant potential is revealed in Fig. 4d. After 3000 cyclic tests at the scanning rate of 0.1 V/s, the catalytic activity remains basically unchanged. In order to more accurately characterize the intrinsic activities of the catalyst, the mass activity (Ir) is used to characterize the intrinsic activities of the catalyst (Fig. S6) (ESI†). IrP2@PC-1.41 also shows higher HER mass activity than other catalysts. Fig. 5 a and b show HER polarization curves of catalysts in acidic electrolytes (0.5 M H2SO4) and overpotentials at the cathode current density of 10 mA·cm−2 (η10), respectively. Among them, IrP2@PC-0.96 just requires a very small overpotential of 15 mV to drive a cathode current density of 10 mA·cm−2, even 12 mV less than that of Pt/C (27 mV), which is one of the smallest overpotentials in the reported TMP catalysts (Table S2) (ESI†). In addition, IrP2@PC-0.63 needs an overpotential of 33 mV for driving a cathode current density of 10 mA·cm−2. As shown in Fig. 5c, the Tafel slopes of IrP2@PC-0.96 and IrP2@PC-0.63 are 33 mV·dec-1 and 32 mV·dec-1, respectively. They are similar to the Tafel slope of Pt/C. As Zheng et al. demonstrated, the overlapping between the polarization curve and the concentration overpotential curve on Pt at this Tafel slope in acid media suggests that the measured current is H2 diffusion limited rather than HER kinetics [48]. Importantly, as presented in Fig. 5d, for the IrP2@PC-0.96 electrode, after continuously electrolyzed at a constant potential for 20 h, the current density also stays stable. After 3000 CV cycle test at a sweep rate of 100 mV/s, the catalytic activity also almost remains unchanged, further proving the excellent stability of IrP2@PC catalysts in acidic electrolytes. The electrochemical impedance frequency spectrum (EIS) is shown in Fig. S7 (ESI†), which manifests IrP2@PC just need a quite small reaction resistance for catalysis. Also, it is worth noting that, IrP2@PC still has a brilliant HER in neutral media (1 M PBS) (Fig. 6 ). As presented in Fig. 6a and b, it only takes IrP2@PC-0.96 a very low overpotential of 32 mV to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm−2, which is 5 mV lower than Pt/C (37 mV). Its corresponding Tafel slope is 65 mV·dec-1, 13 mV·dec-1 lower than that of Pt/C (78 mV·dec-1). Meanwhile, we also measured the cyclic stability under a neutral condition. The continuous water electrolysis on the IrP2@PC-0.96 electrode for 10 h at a constant potential is exhibited in Fig. 6d. After 1000 cycles at the scanning rate of 0.1 V/s, almost no changes of the catalytic activity for IrP2@PC-0.96 can be found. As shown in Fig. 7 , from TEM and HAADF-STEM, and EDX element mapping, after 3000 cycles in 1 M KOH the IrP2 nanoparticles of IrP2@PC-1.41 are still evenly distributed on the P-doped C substrate without agglomeration. The number of O elements in the EDX element mapping increases, which is mainly from the 1 M KOH electrolyte. As presented in Fig. S8 (ESI†), Fig. S9 (ESI†) and Fig. 7, the XPS of IrP2@PC-1.41 before and after 3000 cycles were performed. In the high-resolution P 2p spectrum of IrP2@PC-1.41, the peak at 134.8 eV is assigned to P-O which disappears after 3000 cycles. The peaks of P-Ir (129.6 eV), Ir 4+ 4f 7/2 and Ir 4+ 4f 5/2 have no significant changes, indicating the high electrochemical stability of IrP2@PC catalysts in the accelerated HER process. In addition, the Faradaic yield of hydrogen production is very important for the practical application of catalysts in water splitting. As shown in Fig. 8 , IrP2@PC-1.41 exhibits nearly 100% Faradaic yield, confirming the high electron utilization of IrP2@PC-1.41. 3.3 Mechanism analysis To confirm the improved mechanism of HER electrocatalysis for IrP2@PC catalysts, some intrinsic properties of catalysts were explored by comprehensive analysis. According to nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherm, IrP2@PC has high specific surface area (1182.5 m2·g−1) based on the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) model, and shows the characteristic microporous and mesoporous structure (Fig. S4) (ESI†). Due to the higher BET value of the material, the IrP2 nanoparticles are sufficiently dispersed to expose more active sites and could own larger ECSA. Furthermore, the highest Cdl value of 70.3 mF cm−2 and a high ECSA value of 1757.5 cm2 (Fig. 9 a and Fig. S10 (ESI†)) for IrP2@PC-1.41 are confirmed by CV measurements. These facilitate the effective accessibility of the intrinsic active site. Note that, the porous structure of IrP2@PC also has better mass transfer and charge transfer capacity, which synergistically improves the catalytic efficiency [49,50]. The presence of porous P-doped carbon layers can not only effectively promote the catalysis by means of coordination with IrP2 and high electrical conductivity, but also prevent agglomeration between IrP2 nanoparticles and protect them from heavy corrosion during the catalytic process, improving the activity and stability of catalysts. As shown in Fig. 9b, the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) of IrP2@PC-1.41 manifests that it just needs a quite small electrochemical reaction resistance for catalysis in 1 M KOH solutions due to the rich active site and high electrical conductivity. It can be evidenced that Ir moieties are the main active center of HER electrocatalysis for IrP2@PC. By contrast, Ir/C and metal-free P-doped carbon layer (PC) catalysts need more than 300 mV overpotentials to drive the overpotential at current density of 10 mA·cm−2. In addition, by using a very small amount of Ir (0.63–1.41 wt%), it makes the catalytic performance of IrP2@PC significantly elevated, indicating that Ir moieties provide more active sites. In addition, among IrP2@PC catalysts, IrP2@PC-1.41 owns a remarkably high performance in the alkaline medium, which means more metal loading is conducive to catalyze the HER under alkaline conditions. From the XPS, TEM, (HAADF-STEM), and EDX element mapping analysis of IrP2@PC-1.41 before and after 3000 cycles, it proves that more Ir loading is conducive to catalyze the HER under alkaline conditions, demonstrating that IrP2 is the main catalytic active site. In addition, the interaction between Ir and P can regulate the outer electron structure of Ir, and optimize the affinity of Ir for hydrogen, thus increasing the rate of hydrogen generation. For XPS of IrP2@PC, the peak at 129.8 eV presents a slightly negatively shift relative to the peak of the standard P2p3, indicating that Ir and P in IrP2@PC bear a partial positive charge (δ+) and a partial negative charge (δ−), respectively. These findings point to a weak electron transfer from Ir to P in IrP2@PC. Theoretically, an excellent HER catalyst should have a moderate hydrogen adsorption strength to promote proton-coupled electron transfer and release hydrogen. According to the hydrogen evolution reaction volcano plot [51], the iridium material has suitable hydrogen adsorption and desorption energy, near the apex of the volcano plot. Interfacial engineering research on Ir and heteroatom doping have become important methods to improve the nanocatalytic efficiency. According to the DFT calculation in our another work [29], the introduction of phosphorus promotes water adsorption and dissociation kinetics, and IrP2 significantly reduces the proton adsorption energy of Ir, thereby benefiting the surface hydrogen production. The interaction between the metal and phosphorus makes it possible to efficiently adsorb protons and desorb the formed hydrogen molecules. However, in an alkaline medium, since the protons are derived from the dissociation of water, some substances having an affinity for the oxygen-containing functional groups are introduced into the catalyst. For example, a P-doped carbon material greatly contributes to oxygen reduction, which can effectively reduce the energy barrier of hydrolysis reaction. 3.4 ORR performance of catalysts The ORR test of IrP2@PC, Pt/C and Ir/C was carried out in an O2 saturated 0.1 M KOH solution. Surprisingly, IrP2@PC also exhibits excellent ORR performance (Fig. 10 ). Linear Sweep Voltammetry (LSV) curves (Fig. 10a) show that IrP2@PC-0.96 has a half-wave potential (E1/2) of 0.81 V relative to RHE, much higher than Ir/C (0.75 V) and PC, and close to commercial Pt/C (E1/2 = 0.85 V vs. RHE). From the Koutecky–Levich (K–L) curves (Fig. 10c), the calculated electron transfer number (n) of IrP2@PC-0.96 catalyst is approximately 3.98. At the same time, we tested the current versus time (i–t) chronoamperometric response of IrP2@PC-0.96 and Pt/C (Fig. 10d). They were employed at 1600 rpm in the O2‐saturated 0.1 M KOH solution. After 50 000 s operation, we can see the stability of IrP2@PC-0.96 is significantly better than Pt/C. The P-doped carbon in the substrate can modify the distribution of charge on the carbon surface and activate adjacent carbon, which facilitates the ORR catalysis [31,52]. Therefore, we can conclude that, the excellent ORR performance of IrP2@PC comes from IrP2 and the synergy between IrP2 and PC. 4 Conclusion The phosphorus-doped carbon covered IrP2 nanocrystal catalyst (IrP2@PC) is successfully prepared by a facile method. The obtained IrP2@PC exhibits excellent performances in hydrogen evolution reaction over the whole pH range, and oxygen reduction reaction under alkaline conditions, with a very low amount of Ir (approximately 1 wt%). At a current density of 10 mA·cm−2, and in alkaline, acidic and neutral electrolytes, it shows ultralow overpotentials of 10 mV, 15 mV and 32 mV, respectively. Especially, the IrP2@PC catalyst with 0.96 wt% Ir loading, has HER catalytic activity that exceeds commercial Pt/C over the full pH range. In addition, the IrP2@PC catalyst also possesses high ORR performance close to Pt/C in alkaline media. Our work demonstrates a new synthesis method for the high performance IrP2@PC bifunction catalyst toward higher efficient electrolysis of water and oxygen reduction, and the extremely low precious metal loading is conducive to saving environmental resources. Undoubtedly, this work will promote the development of environmentally friendly energy and electrochemical energy conversion devices in terms of our novel catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Ultralow noble metal loading catalyst is one of the current main research trends for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). In this context, we synthesize the phosphorus-doped carbon covered IrP2 catalysts (IrP2@PC) with Ir amount merely about 1 wt% by an extremely simple way. It possesses remarkably high HER performance, exceeding commercial Pt/C and most reported transition metal catalysts in the whole pH range. In alkaline electrolytes, it shows an ultralow overpotential of 10 mV at a current density of 10 mA·cm−2, almost 100% Faradaic yield for hydrogen production, and continuous discharge stability for more than 10 h. At the same time, in acidic and neutral electrolytes, its overpotentials at the same current density are as low as 15 and 32 mV, respectively. Interestingly, linear Sweep Voltammetry (LSV) data present that, under alkaline conditions, IrP2@PC also possesses a half-wave potential of 0.81 V, extremely close to commercial Pt/C catalysts, indicating that the catalyst also possesses outstanding ORR performance.
coredata.dc:title: Phosphorous-doped carbon coordinated iridium diphosphide bifunctional catalyst with ultralow iridium amount for efficient all-pH-value hydrogen evolution and oxygen reduction reactions
